    Head R (cont.) --

    Amendment moved [16th March, 1992],

    "That the sum to be allocated for Head R be reduced by $10 in respect of Code RB 1500 of the Main Estimates." -- [Dr S. Vasoo].

     Mr Ho Peng Kee (Sembawang GRC): Sir, I have three cuts. Can I take them together?

     The Chairman: Yes.

     Mr Ho Peng Kee: Thank you, Sir. My first cut is on the Courtesy Campaign. The Courtesy Campaign has been on for 14 years now. Question: Are Singaporeans more courteous? The Next Lap hopes to build a more gracious Singapore society.

Column: 1098

How can this be done? The promotion of culture and the arts is certainly important. I would like to suggest that a gracious society is also one where the people have a sense of appreciation, an affirming attitude towards each other, as being co-travellers in a journey heading towards a common destiny.

    Sir, my estimation is that the Courtesy Campaign has had uneven success. The overall tone of Singapore society may be more pleasant but there are still many areas of concern, particularly discourteous behaviour on our roads. I feel that part of the reason is that the thrust of this campaign is directed at outward action rather than inward attitude.

    Sir, it is said that action reflects our thinking, our attitudes, our mindset. We can teach a child to say "thank you" but if he does not know the significance of that act, then we have not really taught him well at all. The annual Courtesy Campaign is good only if we consider it as a regular reminder of the need to inculcate good attitudes in our young. The inculcation of positive attitudes in our young, indeed in all Singaporeans, has to be on-going.

    In my view, an important attitude, therefore, is that of wanting to affirm fellow Singaporeans, to build up each other. Let all Singaporeans at every level be involved in translating into reality Government's intention to maximise every Singaporean's potential. This is not just the Government's responsibility. It is everybody's responsibility. And we can start by learning to be appreciative and affirming, then the "thank you" and "sorry" will flow naturally.

    Sir, may I suggest the following as possible themes for the next Courtesy Campaign: Affirming and encouraging each other and the slogan could very well be "Courtesy as an expression of our appreciation" or "Be courteous to express our appreciation."

    I end this cut by asking the Minister's assessment of the annual Courtesy Campaign.

Column: 1099



    Sir, my next cut is on the role of the press in the Next Lap. The media plays an important role in shaping the values of Singaporeans, all the more so, in a fast changing Singapore where traditional values are in danger of being challenged. If left unchecked, Singaporeans can become less cohesive, less communitarian in outlook, less thrifty, less hardworking and less conservative in our sexual behaviour in the Next Lap.

    What is the role of the press in helping to shape positive values in the Next Lap? In particular, my focus today is on sexual immorality. Is it on the rise in Singapore? Are we going the way of the US when we hear stories of promiscuity such as date rapes, sexual harassment on campus and at the workplace, casual sex, sex escapades of political and religious leaders, extra-marital affairs and so on. Will these phenomena emerge in Singapore? Or have they already taken a foothold? I do not think so. However, Singapore is a global city open to the influence of the world. We are not impervious to world trends. I am concerned that in a Singapore that is becoming more pressurising immoral sexual behaviour and the pleasures they may bring may become an escape valve.

    Recently, Singaporeans read about the happening at Gay Beach along East Coast Park. Divorces, we hear and read, are also on the rise in Singapore, possibly reflecting a rise in the number of extra-marital affairs. There is a significant number of teenage abortions in Singapore. We read of Singaporeans keeping second wives in Batam. Are these indications that something is amiss, and that more has to be done in this area?

    The media can help. Here I would just focus on the media in the written form. While I recognise that the newspapers and magazines must sell enough copies to remain profitable, a balance again must be struck. I have observed that it has become fashionable nowadays for magazines to carry one or two articles centred on a

Column: 1100

sexual theme - some serious and helpful, others sensational and quite frivolous. In this regard, I must compliment the Straits Times in not flowing with the tide. I have found the articles mainly helpful, many purveying positive attitudes.

    However, I just want to join my colleague, Mr Peh Chin Hua, in expressing regret on an article entitled "Single and a Parent" in the Life! section of the Straits Times published on 4th March. While accepting that the article attempts to be balanced and to present different viewpoints as to the reasons for and the problems of single motherhood, it, nevertheless, does give the impression that single motherhood is a socially acceptable and viable option to marriage and having children. I just want to ask the Minister for his views on the need for the press to be more careful not to purvey harmful values to Singaporeans, particularly our young.

    Sir, my third cut is a short one. It is on censorship. Yesterday, my colleague, Dr Vasoo, has already brought up this point and the Minister of State, Dr Ker, has replied and I am glad to hear that we are not about to further relax the rules on censorship. Dr Ker said that there are two types of Singaporeans who go to view R(A) movies -- the curious and the mature. May I suggest, Sir, that there may be a third category -- the hardcore. These are people who may have started off as being curious but even though we know the axiom "curiosity kills the cat" in this case, curiosity feeds the appetite and therefore from being merely curious they become regular visitors to these shows. Worse still, some of these people may have started off with being mature, but again here they become addicted to it and hence join the group of the hardcore.

    We all know that the show "The Unbearable Lightness of Being" has been showing for a long time now, more than three months. It will be interesting to see how many of these people who go to these shows are actually repeaters, people who go more than once. Although we cannot find it out, it will be interesting to see, if

Column: 1101

they do that, what is the motivation for doing so. Is it out of artistic appreciation or are they motivated by something more basic and instinct?

    On this point, I just want to suggest whether some study can be done to see whether or not there is some nexus between the lowering of censorship rules with the incidence of violence and sexual crimes. I note, for example, last year, other offences all went down, but the incidents of murder and outraging of modesty went up by 11% and 5% respectively. Question: is there any nexus?

    The second area would be the relationship between what we have done in terms of censorship rules and secret society activities and, thirdly, it will be interesting to see whether there is any correlation between that and the incidence of extra-marital affairs in Singapore. I would just like to ask the Minister whether he can update us on the progress of the Censorship Review Committee.

     Mr Goh Choon Kang (Braddell Heights): Sir, it is disconcerting to read recent articles in the English press renouncing Mandarin as one's mother tongue. One such article is "No dialect, no culture" in the Business Times (weekend edition, 15th February, 1992). A more recent article is "Why Mandarin is not my mother tongue" in the Sunday Times of 23rd February, 1992.

    Sir, the Speak Mandarin Campaign was first launched more than a decade ago. I do not think I need to go over the reasons for doing so. Suffice it for me to say that these articles remind us that the mission of the campaign is far from completed. In fact, these articles show that many Singaporeans are still confused. Perhaps the recent policy by the Ministry of Education to allow the use of dialect names in registration has caused some misunderstanding. It may have given the wrong impression that the Government is reversing its policy.

    I therefore hope that the Minister can clarify this misconception and outline future plans to further promote the Speak Mandarin Campaign.

Column: 1102



     The Minister for Information and the Arts (BG George Yong-Boon Yeo): Sir, let me first clarify to Dr Vasoo that MITA is responsible for only two campaigns -- the Courtesy Campaign and the Speak Mandarin Campaign -- for which the budget allocated this year is $700,000 and $450,000, which is the same as last year. We do monitor results by surveys although the survey results are not always conclusive.

    Let me start first with the Courtesy Campaign. Have we become more courteous as a people? I say yes. Three months ago, there was a survey which yielded the result that three in four Singaporeans felt that Singaporeans were making the effort and that they themselves have become more courteous. These are very subjective impressions, but it shows that we have been making some progress.

    Is there room for improvement? I think there is plenty of room for improvement. I dare say that the day when we are smug and satisfied, that is the day when we are going downward. It is because we are never satisfied, we are always checking ourselves and criticising ourselves that we maintain standards and we maintain good progress. Of course, attitudes take years and sometimes generations to change and we can change the form very quickly but the inner self, the cultural character of a people, takes much longer to transform.

    I can do no more than quote Senior Minister Mr Lee Kuan Yew when he launched the first campaign in 1979. At that time, I was still in the army. I was very intrigued by the campaign when it was launched. When I was cleaning my cupboard the other day, I saw the article, and I said, "Ah, it may be something to re-read." And indeed an made exactly the same point which Mr Ho Peng Kee makes today. Mr Lee said:

    "To be courteous to free-spending tourists and to be rude to fellow Singaporeans is to demean ourselves. Then we would become a despicable people, moved only by the thought of profit."

He moved on to say that there are two aspects of courtesy, first, the form; second, the sincerity. Forms can be changed quickly, and sincerity will take much

Column: 1103

longer. But Mr Lee said, "even if it is difficult to be sincerely polite, nevertheless, it is better and necessary to keep up polite forms rather than be rude." In other words, we have both short-term goals and long-term goals.
12.45 pm

    The challenge really is how do we keep up the mood of the campaign, to keep it fresh and interesting. And here we need creative ideas and I will ask my Ministry to consult Mr Ho for ideas on how we can keep it vigorous. From this year onwards, we are going to move our area of attention to specific sectors. And for this year, MITA will be working with the Ministry of Communications to give emphasis to courtesy in the transportation sector.

    I would like to move on now to the Speak Mandarin Campaign.

     Mr Chiam See Tong (Potong Pasir): Sir, before the Minister moves on, can I get a clarification with regard to courtesy?

     The Chairman: All right.

     Mr Chiam See Tong: Sir, he asked for ideas. I think the proper place to cultivate courtesy would be in our schools. Each child goes through six years in primary school, four years in secondary school and another two years in pre-university. You have got 12 years to teach courtesy to our children.

    The Courtesy Campaign has been going on for 14 years. That is more than the number of years a child spends in school. I think it would be the proper thing to make it a way of life of our people and this can be done in our schools, rather than spending $700,000 every year, which I think is a waste of money.

     BG George Yong-Boon Yeo: Sir, we do promote the courtesy campaign in the schools and it has been a multi-faceted comprehensive approach. The idea of a campaign is to give it a special emphasis for a short period of time so that it will eventually become a way of life. That is the objective, to make it a way of life. How do we get there? By campaigns. So the two

Column: 1104

are not in contradiction. In fact, our idea should be to get the message not just to the schools, but in the end to the homes, which means to the parents. The parents themselves might not have had the training or the education in their own times.

    Let me now move on to the Speak Mandarin Campaign. I would like here to report that good progress has been made. A survey conducted last year showed that for last year, in markets and hawker centres, 24% of Chinese Singaporeans used Mandarin as compared to 1% in 1979. A survey conducted by SPH recently showed that, compared to six years ago, among family members, the use of Mandarin had doubled. These are again rough indicators, but it shows that we have made progress and I think this is confirmed by our own subjective impression when we go around.

    I assure Mr Goh Choon Kang that Government's commitment to the Speak Mandarin Campaign remains unchanged, and I would go so far as to say -- I mentioned this in the House last year -- that the problem now is not so much dialect versus Mandarin, but mother tongue versus English. It becomes so convenient to use English in our place of work, in Government, in the shopping centres, that there is a danger that we may give less emphasis to the mother tongue, which would be wrong because that will deprive us of the life blood of our cultural heritage. So we should continue to promote Mandarin, we should continue to promote the other mother tongues.

    Concerning the recent spate of articles in the Straits Times about dialects being the mother tongue, I think those views are mistaken and lack a historical understanding of the promotion of Mandarin in the whole movement of Chinese nationalism. The first Speak Mandarin Campaign in Singapore was not 10 years or 12 years ago, it was in the 1920s. Someone sent me an article the other day showing that as early as the 1920s, we had Speak Mandarin Campaigns in Singapore. And this is not surprising because it was an integral part of the Chinese Republican revolution. In 1911, when they threw out the Manchus, a

Column: 1105

Chinese nation had to be forged, big debate at that time in Canton as to which would be the national language of China. Should it be Cantonese or should it be Mandarin? In the end, they decided on Mandarin because Mandarin was the kuan hua. Mandarin was the official language in imperial China. Mandarin is from the word man da ren, the Manchu big shot, the Manchu official. So by a narrow margin, they decided on Mandarin as the unifying language of China. And naturally, this was also promoted among the overseas Chinese communities in South East Asia, including Singapore.

    No traditional dialect speaker disputes this. The older Singaporeans who speak only dialects, no Mandarin, they will readily concede that Mandarin must be the common language of all Chinese. And if you are able to speak good Mandarin, it is the mark of an educated person. So I found the views expressed in the Straits Times recently rather puzzling and rather sadly lacking in a historical understanding of the progress of Chinese culture and the Chinese nation.

    The question then is: should we also support dialects? I say it is very difficult. We already have four official languages and if we also support dialects - and there are so many of them, six or seven - where do we start, where do we end? So it is not possible for the state or the Government to promote dialects.

    Having said that, should we suppress dialects? Should we make it so uncomfortable for people to use dialects that those who use it feel suppressed? Actually, that is also wrong. In Taiwan, for years, they kept down dialects. And when the political system there was loosened, as part of the campaign against the mainlanders, Hokkien , min nan hua, became a big issue, because min nan hua was promoted and politicians had to use min nan hua. So ke jia, Hakka, also came to the fore. I think about 15% of the Taiwanese are Hakkas.

    Whether or not Singaporeans will continue to use dialects does not depend on developments in Singapore alone. I say it depends on developments in East Asia, in South China, Hong Kong and Taiwan,

Column: 1106

because if those large population centres continue to use dialects, then it is natural that Singaporeans who do business there, who have cultural contacts there, will also want to use dialects. Because if they speak it and you speak it to a greater or lesser extent, it creates a certain empathy. As Parliamentarians, as MPs, when you go down to the ground, from time to time, you use dialects to show that we are one. This is a long historical process. How it will evolve, we do not know. In China itself, it is an issue. Recently, they are trying to promote the use of Mandarin in the south, because today in the southern cities, virtually only dialect is spoken. Last year, when I visited Swatow University, I called on the President and the first thing he did -- he is a Shanghainese -- was to apologise for speaking to me in Mandarin and not in Teochew, because there was social pressure on him.

    In China, in Hong Kong, in Taiwan, the debate is still going on. When we have to send someone to Hong Kong, we find a Cantonese speaker. When Dr Aline Wong went there to open a twinning conference a few months ago, she spoke in Cantonese. When we have to find a representative in Taipei, we make sure that, in addition to Mandarin, he speaks Hokkien.

    But these are necessities. We speak dialect in the same way as we have also to learn Japanese, German or Malay when we go out and trade, to make a living, to establish cultural contacts. We cannot make it an official language, we cannot promote it officially. So I would put it like this. In the long-term, Mandarin will become established as a common language of all Chinese Singaporeans. And some Chinese Singaporeans will know dialects to a greater or lesser degree because they find that it makes it useful for them to carry out their business, cultural or political activities.

    I would now like to turn to the question of the role of the press in upholding moral standards in our society, the point raised by Mr Ho Peng Kee. I think the media does play a very important role. It is not the only player, but it does play a very important role. The role of Government really is to

Column: 1107

draw the outer limits. So we can draw the outer limit at R or R(A) or whatever. But within these limits, I think it is for different groups in our community to exert influence, to take moral high ground. It is very difficult for Government to say, "Look, see this film, not that film, because this film is more edifying than the other film." But parents can do it, religious leaders can do it, school teachers can do it, community leaders can do it, and that is fine. And I think this is how we should approach this problem. It is right that as a society, we are continuously vexed by concerns about moral standards, because like courtesy, the moment we show no concern, that is the surest sign of decline. It is because we are worried, we are anxious all the time, that standards are held up and maintained.

    But at the same time, we are not a Victorian society. We cannot be. Every year, we get over 5 million visitors through Changi airport, plus millions more down the Causeway. Every year, over a million Singaporeans travel overseas. We are a society utterly ventilated. Our trade is so many times our GNP. So there is no way we can put up a cordon sanitaire around Singapore and say, "Ok, within this area, it is hermetically sealed." And the technology will not allow us to exercise these controls in the future.

    Yesterday, I talked about satellite broadcasting. Then you have CDs, laser discs. Now we go through the motion of checking every video cassette that comes in. We say, you declare, you pay a fee. We have a small platoon of censors who will go through fast-forward every video cassette. I do not think it does their eyes any good. Anyway, they have to go through, it is their job. That is possible with video cassettes. But how do we do a 100% check of optical discs? It is not possible. You can put the text of the whole Encyclopedia Britannica on a video disc. Furthermore, some parts may be locked by passwords and if you are scanning through, you may not even know that there are secret sections which you have not been accessing. So we have to

Column: 1108

take a practical approach that whatever we do, there will be leakages into our society. But what we do not want is for it to become blatant, for it to be sold in the shops, for it to be promoted in our media, particularly the establishment media, by which I refer to the Straits Times, Lianhe Zaobao, Berita Harian, Tamil Murasu and the television stations. They must maintain certain standards. Our schools also and the universities. They define what is respectable. In any society, there is the seedier, seamier, side. I think that can never be fully solved. It is like prostitution. You can control prostitution, but you cannot stop it.

    I would say we must maintain moral standards and the press plays a very important role but, at the same time, we must recognise the way we have been influenced by the world outside in which we live and from which we cannot be completely insulated. We have to take a realistic and practical approach, recognise that we are not, and we do not want to be, a Victorian society, but we want to maintain certain standards in our home, so that it may be dirty outside, but when you come back home, remove your shoes, wear your slippers, come in. A society where it is safe to bring up children, a society which keeps up with changes in the world without compromising on the wholesome quality of civic life.

     Dr S. Vasoo (Tanjong Pagar GRC): Sir, I would like to thank the Minister for his response and I beg leave to withdraw the amendment.

1.00 pm

     Mr Goh Choon Kang: Sir, I beg to move,

    That the sum to be allocated for Head R be reduced by $10 in respect of Code RC 1500 of the Main Estimates.

    Sir, in moving this amendment, I am proposing the idea of building smaller neighbourhood libraries in HDB new towns in lieu of the present bigger branch libraries. Sir, in the Addendum to the Presidential Address, the Minister has promised to review the number, size and location of new branch libraries that will

Column: 1109

be needed for the next 10 years. This is a step in the right direction. I welcome the setting up of the Library 2000 Review Committee to re-evaluate the current criteria. What is the current criterion? The current criterion for public library planning is that the new town should have a population of at least 200,000. As such, smaller new towns such as Serangoon New Town with a population base of less than 200,000 does not qualify for a branch library under the current criterion. My constituents, for example, have to travel a relatively long distance to the nearest branch library, which is in Toa Payoh. This can be quite inconvenient. I am sure there are many more other smaller new town residents who feel the same way.

    Sir, life in the new town today is very much centred around the neighbourhood town centres. People go to the town centre to shop, to eat, to get access to various services provided. However, the activities are very much commercial in nature. If a neighbourhood public library can be included, then I think a new cultural dimension can be added. It will certainly enrich the community life. It is, therefore, timely to consider building libraries which are easily accessible. It can form part of a town centre and provide auxiliary facilities such as a lecture hall, a small theatre and study room within the library building. A neighbourhood library can serve as an access point to the National Library resources through inter-library lending and referral services. It can also devote itself to extending its role by including community information and the promotion of library as a centre of art, crafts and visual activity. I think this should rightly be the characteristics of future libraries. I hope the Minister can consider seriously my idea of building neighbourhood libraries in new town centres, including my constituency.

     Mr Teo Chong Tee (Changi): Sir, I just want to ask the Minister whether he has any plan to provide the service of a mobile library in my constituency.

     Dr Vasoo: Sir, the library services have improved quite dramatically over the last few years. I feel that it is time to review

Column: 1110

whether we should bring library services to the neighbourhood where smaller libraries could be made available. There are a lot of young children who, because of safety and accessibility, may not be able to travel quite a distance to the central libraries. If we are going to promote better reading habits, and the earlier use of library facilities, such neighbourhood library facilities will be very useful indeed.

    Having a good library is not sufficient, Sir, because one needs to review the opening hours of these libraries. I think there is an urgency to assess this because we have mothers who are working during the day and we have a growing number of senior citizens who need to use the library. They have, in fact, sounded to me that many of these libraries do not open in the early hours of the morning. If we are going to popularise library facilities and allow maximum use of them, there is indeed an urgency to review the opening hours of libraries during the weekdays and weekends. I hope the Minister, in considering the extension of these libraries, will look at the opening hours of these libraries.

     The Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Information and the Arts (Encik Mohamad Maidin B P M): Sir, I am replying on behalf of my Minister.
